qas.question: In alpha male mandrills what party of the body is most red according to their rank?
Wearing red is connected to what result in humans, in terms of sport?
In what sport have judges been shown to favor athletes wearing red?
What is the effect of exposing a human to red when it comes to cognitive skills?
The amount of red in mandrill males is directly related to levels of what?
What are blue shapes most likely to win?

plausible_answers.text: cognitive tasks and elicits aversion in psychological tests where subjects are placed in an "achievement" context (e.g. taking an IQ test).

qas.question: What does exposure to red increase performance in?

plausible_answers.text: increased performance in competitions, including professional sport and multiplayer video games

qas.question: What has wearing blue been linked with?
What can blue affect the perception of by others?

context: Red is associated with dominance in a number of animal species. For example, in mandrills, red coloration of <a0_0>the face<a0_0/> is greatest in alpha males, increasingly less prominent in lower ranking subordinates, and directly correlated with levels of <a4_0>testosterone<a4_0/>. Red can also affect the perception of <b8_0>dominance<b8_0/> by others, leading to significant differences in mortality, reproductive success and parental investment between individuals displaying red and those not. In humans, wearing red has been linked with <a1_0><b7_0>increased performance<a1_0/> in competitions, including professional sport and multiplayer video games<b7_0/>. Controlled tests have demonstrated that wearing red does not increase performance or levels of testosterone during exercise, so the effect is likely to be produced by perceived rather than actual performance. Judges of <a2_0>tae kwon do<a2_0/> have been shown to favor competitors wearing red protective gear over blue, and, when asked, a significant majority of people say that red abstract shapes are more "dominant", "aggressive", and "likely to win <b5_0>a physical competition<b5_0/>" than blue shapes. In contrast to its positive effect in physical competition and dominance behavior, exposure to red <a3_0>decreases performance<a3_0/> in <b6_0>cognitive tasks and elicits aversion in psychological tests where subjects are placed in an "achievement" context (e.g. taking an IQ test).
